articles.headline: Syria War Stirs New U.S. Debate on Cyberattacks
articles.snippet: Considerations that led President Obama to hesitate about using cyberweapons against Syria reflect larger concerns about a new and untested tactic.
articles.abstract: Considerations that led President Obama to hesitate about using cyberweapons against Syria reflect larger concerns about a new and untested tactic.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Not long after the uprising in Syria turned bloody, late in the spring of 2011, the Pentagon and the National Security Agency developed a battle plan that featured a sophisticated cyberattack on the Syrian military and President Bashar al-Assad’s command structure.

articles.headline: Holder Sees Way to Curb Bans on Gay Marriage
articles.snippet: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said that state attorneys general who believe that laws in their states banning same-sex marriage are discriminatory are not obligated to defend them.
articles.abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said that state attorneys general who believe that laws in their states banning same-sex marriage are discriminatory are not obligated to defend them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Monday injected the Obama administration into the emotional and politicized debate over the future of state same-sex marriage bans, declaring in an interview that state attorneys general are not obligated to defend laws that they believe are discriminatory.

articles.headline: Target Push Into Canada Stumbles
articles.snippet: Shoppers’ habits and other factors figure into a projected $800 million to $900 million loss in the retailer’s first international expansion.
articles.abstract: Shoppers’ habits and other factors figure into a projected $800 million to $900 million loss in the retailer’s first international expansion.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — When Canadians crossed the border into the United States on shopping excursions, Target was a prime destination. But when Target crossed the border last year and brought its stores to Canada, the magic somehow vanished.

articles.headline: Steel Industry Feeling Stress as Automakers Turn to Aluminum
articles.snippet: Steel makers are responding by producing lighter, stronger steel in a bid to retain one of their most important customers.
articles.abstract: Steel makers are responding by producing lighter, stronger steel in a bid to retain one of their most important customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich. — For nearly a century, Ford’s River Rouge factory and its neighboring steel mill have worked in close harmony to produce some of America’s most popular vehicles, from the Model A to the F-150 pickup truck.

articles.headline: For Same-Sex Marrieds, a Tax Season to Look Back
articles.snippet: The I.R.S. allows couples the option of filing amended returns for the last three years, if they so choose. For some unions, this could mean a nice refund.
articles.abstract: The I.R.S. allows couples the option of filing amended returns for the last three years, if they so choose. For some unions, this could mean a nice refund.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tax season doesn’t usually stir up emotions about the meaning of family and equal rights.

articles.headline: Colorblind Notion Aside, Colleges Grapple With Racial Tension
articles.snippet: Racial tensions are playing out in new ways on college campuses nationwide, like the University of Michigan, which has seen a sharp decline in black undergraduate enrollment.
articles.abstract: Racial tensions are playing out in new ways on college campuses nationwide, like the University of Michigan, which has seen a sharp decline in black undergraduate enrollment.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — A brochure for the University of Michigan features a vision of multicultural harmony, with a group of students from different racial backgrounds sitting on a verdant lawn, smiling and conversing.

articles.headline: Pension Funds Sue on a Deal Gone Cold
articles.snippet: Alphonse Fletcher Jr., a flashy hedge fund manager, has been accused of running something akin to a Ponzi scheme, and the pension systems that say he misled them are hoping to get their money back.
articles.abstract: Alphonse Fletcher Jr., a flashy hedge fund manager, has been accused of running something akin to a Ponzi scheme, and the pension systems that say he misled them are hoping to get their money back.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sitting around a table in Baton Rouge, La., in February 2008, a handful of board members of the Firefighters’ Retirement System of Louisiana heard an investment pitch that would later come back to haunt them.

articles.headline: U.S. and Britain Join Forces in Bank Misbehavior Cases
articles.snippet: British and American authorities investigating bad behavior at large banks have reached an uneasy truce.
articles.abstract: British and American authorities investigating bad behavior at large banks have reached an uneasy truce.
articles.lead_paragraph: It seemed to be a thumb in the eye of the Justice Department. Britain last week criminally charged a former Barclays employee suspected of trying to manipulate global interest rates, even though the authorities in London were aware that the employee had been assisting American prosecutors in a related investigation for more than a year.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Ben Protess

articles.headline: @GSElevator Tattletale Exposed (He Was Not in the Goldman Elevator)
articles.snippet: The person posting as @GSElevator on Twitter, thought to be a Goldman Sachs employee, is actually a 34-year-old former bond trader in Texas.
articles.abstract: The person posting as @GSElevator on Twitter, thought to be a Goldman Sachs employee, is actually a 34-year-old former bond trader in Texas.
articles.lead_paragraph: A three-year parlor game has been taking place on Wall Street to identify the Goldman Sachs employee behind a Twitter account that purports to reveal the uncensored comments overheard in the firm’s elevators.

articles.headline: Wary Stance From Obama on Ukraine
articles.snippet: While George W. Bush was inspired by Ukraine’s 2004 revolution, Barack Obama has approached the unrest of 2014 with a more clinical detachment aimed at avoiding instability.
articles.abstract: While George W. Bush was inspired by Ukraine’s 2004 revolution, Barack Obama has approached the unrest of 2014 with a more clinical detachment aimed at avoiding instability.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Televisions around the White House were aglow with pictures of Ukrainians in the streets, demanding to be heard and toppling a government aligned with Russia. It was an invigorating moment, and it spurred a president already rethinking his approach to the world.

articles.headline: In Venezuela, Protest Ranks Grow Broader
articles.snippet: In a coordinated action against the government, residents of Caracas and other cities have taken to the streets to protest a litany of problems that have long troubled the country.
articles.abstract: In a coordinated action against the government, residents of Caracas and other cities have taken to the streets to protest a litany of problems that have long troubled the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN CRISTÓBAL, Venezuela — As dawn broke, the residents of a quiet neighborhood here readied for battle. Some piled rocks to be used as projectiles. Others built barricades. A pair of teenagers made firebombs as the adults looked on.

articles.headline: Apparent Theft at Mt. Gox Shakes Bitcoin World
articles.snippet: The prominent Bitcoin exchange was said to be on the verge of total collapse following a major theft, even as another company announced plans for a high-profile virtual currency market.
articles.abstract: The prominent Bitcoin exchange was said to be on the verge of total collapse following a major theft, even as another company announced plans for a high-profile virtual currency market.
articles.lead_paragraph: The most prominent Bitcoin exchange appeared to be on the verge of collapse late Monday, raising questions about the future of a volatile marketplace.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Rachel Abrams
